Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Impacts of Post-Hurricane Land-Atmosphere Interactions on Convective and Precipitation Processes in the Caribbean Region
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of Hurricane Maria's devastating impacts was a significant landscape change to Puerto Rico from the extreme winds and flooding rains. As the island recovers, this project will provide funding for a research team to study how land surface changes may impact storm development and intensification in the Caribbean. The award will provide funding for the refurbishment and replacement of some existing research infrastructure, and new instruments to measure the energy balance of the land surface. Observations will be compared with numerical model simulations to answer questions about storm initiation and invigoration. The long-term impact of this study will be an improved capacity to predict extreme precipitation, which has implications for public safety and water resource management. The research team will also work with stakeholders in Puerto Rico to provide scientifically sound information to increase their resilience to natural disasters.

The research team plans to improve understanding of the role played by modified land-atmosphere interactions in storm development and intensification in the Caribbean. The researchers believe that the land surface changes due to Hurricane Maria could provide a unique contrasting scenario to accelerate understanding of storm initiation and invigoration. The team plans to update an existing observational network to include surface energy flux sensors and to repair some of the existing equipment that was damaged by Maria. A comprehensive energy balance site will be established to record sensible, latent and carbon dioxide fluxes. Two intensive observing periods will be conducted with radiosonde launches and an aerosol speciation sampler. Varied land surface configurations will be conducted using the RAMS model and tested against the observations. Four research questions are at the core of the project: 1) How does the modified landscape impact the local surface energy and water budgets? 2) How do the changes in local energy and water budgets impact convection during the rainfall seasons? 3) In the context of a changed landscape, how do the local land-atmosphere processes interact with large scale events like Saharan dust advection that influence cloud formation and rainfall? 4) How will these geophysical changes impact the recovering local community? Particularly, how vulnerable are they to flooding and what are the challenges to the agricultural sector?

POR.DRECONTENT:
The RAPID grant helped us to investigate the impacts of Hurricane Maria on Puerto Rico?s climatology, particularly quantify the landcover damage and the associated effects on the surface-atmosphere coupling. As part of the project, continuous observations of the surface-atmosphere exchanges were made in Puerto Rico in 2018 and currently continuing. The surface-atmosphere exchanges were monitored using a comprehensive energy balance station, installed through the project. Additionally 2 intensive field campaigns were conducted during the Summer and early Autumn months wherein the boundary layer development was closely monitored using radiosonde launches and boundary layer profilers. An extensive landcover analysis using unmanned aerial vehicle was conducted following the hurricane. The results from the aerial observations were coupled with high resolution satellite images to determine the landcover damage due to hurricane Maria. Overall the research has found the following: a) The landcover analysis has revealed that large section of the forest cover has been destroyed by the hurricane; nearly 80% of the forest cover has been destroyed and been replaced by pasture and barren land, b) The landcover damage has severely impacted the Island?s surface energy balance; our numerical simulations indicate significant increase in latent heat fluxes during the midday period in the months following the hurricane, c) The precipitation pattern in the Island has been drastically altered; during the dry season following the hurricane the monthly precipitation totals in the northern and western regions of the island has increased by 50%. 

 

The results from our landcover analysis is detailed in the publication titled, ?Impact of hurricane Maria on Puerto Rico?s landcover and precipitation?, which is currently under review in the journal, Natural Hazards and Earth System Sciences. The results were also presented at the American Geophysical Union conference 2018 held  in Washington DC. Two other publications are under preparation; the numerical study detailing the modifications in land-atmosphere coupling will be submitted to the Journal of Geophysical Research- Atmospheres and the study detailing the impact of surface forcing and saharan dust on precipitation will be submitted to the International Journal of Climatology.

 

The RAPID grant has allowed us to establish pivotal partnerships with local researchers and stakeholders, particularly resources created through the grant - the energy balance site and the weather station - has been shared with researchers in University of Puerto Rico, Mayaguez. Data from the stations are currently used to develop agriculture-focussed weather products. The energy balance site is currently used to explore the potential for renewable energy generation in Western Puerto Rico. One of the priorities of the project was to drastically improve the observational facilities in Puerto Rico that will provide vital data for future research. In addition to the energy balance site that is currently active, we have upgraded the  weather stations that were damaged due to the hurricane in Mayaguez, with high resolution and high accuracy instruments. The Ceilometer  and air quality sensor which were damaged was also repaired.

 

The grant  was used to train a Post Doctoral researcher; four undergraduate students were directly funded through the project - 3 through the research education for undergrad?s program (REU) and 1 as a research assistant. Two REU?s and the research assistant were from University of Puerto Rico, Mayaguez; the other REU is currently a student at CCNY- the host institution. All the Undergraduate students (2 males and 2 females) and the Post Doc were from communities underrepresented in STEM. The Post Doc trained through the project is currently working as tenured track faculty at CUNY Laguardia Community College in New York. Two REU?s have graduated and currently work as engineers at Boeing and US Navy; 2 other REU?s are still in college.
